introduction.p: In the previous section we saw that inverse variation can be expressed as a power function by using negative integer exponents. For example, the function f(x) = \dfrac{k}{x^2} can also be written as f(x)=kx^{-2}. Using negative exponents can simplify many calculations that would otherwise involve algebraic fractions.

But is there some meaning to exponents that are fractions, such as \frac{1}{2} or \frac{1}{3}? For example, do expressions such as 5^{1/2} or a^{1/3} have some familiar interpretation? We'll see that fractional exponents can denote square roots and other radicals.

subsection.title: n^\text{th} Roots
subsection.p: Recall that s is a square root of b if s^2 = b, and s is a cube root of b if s^3 = b. For example, 5 is a square root of 25 because 5^2 = 25, and 2 is a cube root of 8 because 2^3 = 8.
In a similar way, we can define the fourth, fifth, or sixth root of a number. For instance, the fourth root of 81 is the number 3 because 3^4 = 81.

assemblage.title: nth Roots
assemblage.p: s is called an nth root of b if \blert{s^n = b}.

subsection.p: We use the symbol \sqrt[n]{b} to denote the nth root of b. An expression of the form \sqrt[n]{b} is called a radicalradical, b is called the radicandradicand, and n is called the index of the radicalindex (of a radical).

subsection.title: Exponential Notation for Radicals
subsection.p: A convenient notation for radicals uses fractional exponents. Consider the expression 9^{1/2}. What meaning can we attach to an exponent that is a fraction? Recall that when we raise a power to a power, we multiply the exponents together: \left(x^a\right)^b = x^{ab} Therefore, if we square the number 9^{1/2}, we get \left(9^{1/2}\right)^2 = 9^{(1/2)(2)} = 9^1 = 9 Thus, 9^{1/2} is a number whose square is 9. But this means that 9^{1/2} is a square root of 9, or 9^{1/2} =\sqrt{9} = 3

subsection.title: Irrational Numbers
subsection.p: What about nth roots such as \sqrt{23} and 5^{1/3} that cannot be evaluated easily? These are examples of irrational numbersirrational numbers. An irrational number is one that cannot be expressed as a quotient of two integers.

It is not possible to write down an exact decimal equivalent for an irrational number, but we can find an approximation to as many decimal places as we like. ~\alert{\text{[TK]}}~ We can use a calculator to obtain decimal approximations for irrational numbers. For example, you can verify that \sqrt{23} \approx 4.796 ~~~~~ \text{ and } ~~~~~ 5^{1/3}\approx 1.710

subsection.title: Using Fractional Exponents to Solve Equations
subsection.p: We know that raising to powers and taking roots are inverse operations, that is, each operation undoes the effects of the other. This relationship is especially easy to see when the root is denoted by a fractional exponent. For example, to solve the equation x^5 = 250 we would take the fifth root of each side. But instead of using radical notation, we can raise both sides of the equation to the power \dfrac{1}{5}: \left(x^5\right)^{1/5} \amp= 250^{1/5} x \amp \approx 3.017 Notice again that \left(x^a\right)^b = x^{ab}, so \left(x^5\right)^{1/5} = x^{(1/5)(5)} = x^1 Thus, to solve an equation involving a power function x^n, we first isolate the power, then raise both sides to the exponent \dfrac{1}{n}.

statement.p:
For astronomers, the mass of a star is its most important property, but it is also the most difficult to measure directly. For many stars, their luminosity, or brightness, varies roughly as the fourth power of the mass.
Our Sun has luminosity 4 \times 10^{26} watts and mass 2 \times 10^{30} kilograms. Because the numbers involved are so large, astronomers often use these solar constants as units of measure: The luminosity of the Sun is 1 solar luminosity, and its mass is 1 solar mass. Write a power function for the luminosity, L, of a star in terms of its mass, M, using units of solar mass and solar luminosity.
The star Sirius is 23 times brighter than the Sun, so its luminosity is 23 solar luminosities. Estimate the mass of Sirius in units of solar mass.

ol.li: Because L varies as the fourth power of M, we have L = kM^4 Substituting the values of L and M for the Sun (namely, L = 1 and M = 1), we find 1 = k(1)^4 so k = 1 and L = M^4.

We substitute the luminosity of Sirius, L = 23, to get 23 = M^4 To solve the equation for M, we raise both sides to the \dfrac{1}{4} power. (23)^{1/4} \amp = \left(M^4\right)^{1/4} 2.1899 \amp = M The mass of Sirius is about 2.2 solar masses, or about 2.2 times the mass of the Sun.

subsection.title: Solving Radical Equations
subsection.p: A radical equationradical equationequationradicalradical equation is one in which the variable appears under a square root or other radical. The radical may be denoted by a fractional exponent. For example, the equation 5x^{1/3} = 32 is a radical equation because x^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{x}. To solve the equation, we first isolate the power to get x^{1/3} = 6.4 Then we raise both sides of the equation to the reciprocal of \dfrac{1}{3}, or 3. \left(x^{1/3}\right)^3 \amp = 6.4^3 x \amp = 262.144

subsection.title: Roots of Negative Numbers
subsection.p: You already know that \sqrt{-9} is not a real number, because there is no real number whose square is -9. Similarly, \sqrt[4]{-16} is not a real number, because there is no real number r for which r^4 = -16. (Both of these radicals represent complex numberscomplex number.) In general, we cannot find an even root (square root, fourth root, and so on) of a negative number.

On the other hand, every positive number has two even roots that are real numbers. For example, both 3 and -3 are square roots of 9. The symbol \sqrt{9} refers only to the positive, or principal rootprincipal rootrootprincipal rootpositive rootprincipal rootprincipal rootroot, of 9. If we want to refer to the negative square root of 9, we must write -\sqrt{9} = -3. Similarly, both 2 and -2 are fourth roots of 16, because 2^4 = 16 and (-2)^4 = 16. However, the symbol \sqrt[4]{16} refers to the principal, or positive, fourth root only. Thus, \sqrt[4]{16} = 2 ~~ \text{ and } ~~ -\sqrt[4]{16} = -2

Things are simpler for odd roots (cube roots, fifth roots, and so on). Every real number, whether positive, negative, or zero, has exactly one real-valued odd root. For example, \sqrt[5]{32} = 2 ~~ \text{ and } ~~ \sqrt[5]{-32} = -2
Here is a summary of our discussion.

ol.li: Every positive number has two real-valued roots, one positive and one negative, if the index is even.
A negative number has no real-valued root if the index is even.
Every real number, positive, negative, or zero, has exactly one real-valued root if the index is odd.

subsection.p: The same principles apply to powers with fractional exponents. Thus (-32)^{1/5} = -2 but (-64)^{1/6} is not a real number. On the other hand, -64^{1/6} = -2 because the exponent 1/6 applies only to 64, and the negative sign is applied after the root is computed.
